column2: Diagnosing bias in data-driven algorithms for healthcare
column4: Jenna Wiens; W. Nicholson Price; Michael W. Sjoding
column6: University of Michigan; University of Michigan; University of Michigan
column10: This paper presents a comprehensive framework for identifying and diagnosing bias in healthcare algorithms, focusing on clinical decision support systems and their impact on patient outcomes.

column2: Artificial Intelligence in Clinical Decision Support: Challenges for Evaluating AI and Practical Implications
column4: Farah Magrabi; Elske Ammenwerth; Jytte Brender McNair; N. F. de Keizer; Hannele Hyppönen; Pirkko Nykänen; Michael Rigby; Philip Scott; Tuulikki Vehko; Zoie Shui-Yee Wong; Andrew Georgiou
column5: Australia; Austria; Denmark; Netherlands; Finland; Finland; UK; UK; Finland; Japan; Australia
column6: Macquarie University; UMIT - Private Universität für Gesundheitswissenschaften, Medizinische Informatik und Technik; Aalborg University; Amsterdam University Medical Centers; Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare; Tampere University; Keele University; University of Portsmouth; Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare; St. Luke's International University; Macquarie University
column10: This study explores the challenges in evaluating AI systems for clinical decision support and provides practical guidelines for implementation.

column2: Artificial intelligence bias in medical system designs: a systematic review
column4: Ashish Kumar; Vivekanand Aelgani; Rubeena Vohra; Suneet Kumar Gupta; Mrinalini Bhagawati; Sudip Paul; Luca Saba; Neha Suri; Narendra N. Khanna; John R. Laird; Amer M. Johri; Manudeep Kalra; Mostafa M. Fouda; Mostafa Fatemi; Subbaram Naidu; Jasjit S. Suri
column5: India; India; India; India; India; India; Italy; ; ; USA; Canada; USA; USA; USA; USA;
column6: Bennett University; CMR University; Bharati Vidyapeeth Deemed University; Bennett University; North Eastern Hill University; North Eastern Hill University; University of Cagliari; ; ; St. Helena Hospital; Queen's University; Massachusetts General Hospital; Idaho State University; Mayo Clinic; University of Minnesota, Duluth;
column10: Inherent bias in the artificial intelligence (AI)-model brings inaccuracies and variabilities during clinical deployment of the model. It is challenging to recognize the source of bias in AI-model due to variations in datasets and black box nature of system design. Additionally, there is no distinct process to identify the potential source of bias in the AI-model. To the best of our knowledge, this is the first review of its kind that addresses the bias in AI-model by categorizing 48 studies into three classes, namely, point-based, image-based, and hybrid-based AI-models. Selection strategy using PRISMA is adopted to select the 72 crucial AI studies for identifying bias in AI models. Using the three classes, bias is identified in these studies based on 44 critical AI attributes. Bias in the AI-models is computed by analytical, butterfly, and ranking-based bias models. These bias models were evaluated using two experts and compared using variability analysis. AI-studies that lacked sufficient AI-attributes are more prone to risk-of-bias (RoB) in all three classes. Studies with high RoB loses fins in the butterfly model. It has been analyzed that the majority of the studies in healthcare suffer from data bias and algorithmic bias due to incomplete specifications mentioned in the design protocol and weak AI design exploited for prediction.

column2: Inherent Bias in Artificial Intelligence-Based Decision Support Systems for Healthcare
column4: Varadraj P. Gurupur; Thomas T. H. Wan
column6: University of Central Florida; University of Central Florida
column10: The objective of this article is to discuss the inherent bias involved with artificial intelligence-based decision support systems for healthcare. In this article, the authors describe some relevant work published in this area. A proposed overview of solutions is also presented. The authors believe that the information presented in this article will enhance the readers’ understanding of this inherent bias and add to the discussion on this topic. Finally, the authors discuss an overview of the need to implement transdisciplinary solutions that can be used to mitigate this bias.
